papers.abstract: The government of the United Kingdom is offering significant amounts of funding to increase engagement between researchers and technology companies involved in the 'creative economy,' a sector worth £100b per annum. The sector has naturally evolved into clusters involving actors as diverse as the BBC, the Victoria and Albert Museum, and freelance game designers. It collaborates and competes with multinational powerhouses including Google, Microsoft, and Pixar. The imbrication of academic researchers in the sector makes it a good example of the extension of academia to industry, raising ethical but also methodological and practical questions. This article describes a project that embedded a research software engineer (RSE) from a digital humanities (DH) laboratory into a small technology start-up engaged in high-risk R&D of an immersive narrative storytelling platform. The platform is enabled by artificial intelligence and has the capacity to remember user input and modify narrative options and character mood accordingly. The team included a researcher specializing in narrative theory and digital production. The project demonstrated the utility of the critical application of DH methods and the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry.

events.Text: The government of the United Kingdom is offering significant amounts of funding to increase engagement between researchers and technology companies involved in the 'creative economy,' a sector worth £100b per annum. The sector has naturally evolved into clusters involving actors as diverse as the BBC, the Victoria and Albert Museum, and freelance game designers. It collaborates and competes with multinational powerhouses including Google, Microsoft, and Pixar. The imbrication of academic researchers in the sector makes it a good example of the extension of academia to industry, raising ethical but also methodological and practical questions.

This article describes a project that embedded a research software engineer (RSE) from a digital humanities (DH) laboratory into a small technology start-up engaged in high-risk R&D of an immersive narrative storytelling platform. The platform is enabled by artificial intelligence and has the capacity to remember user input and modify narrative options and character mood accordingly. The team included a researcher specializing in narrative theory and digital production.

Agent: a research software engineer from a digital humanities laboratory

Primary Object: an immersive narrative storytelling platform developed by a small technology start-up

events.Text: The project demonstrated the utility of the critical application of DH methods and the need to develop career pipelines to produce people capable of working at the intersection of higher education and industry.

papers.abstract: My Day of DH (Digital Humanities) 2020 included an hour-long talk with a social media platform about diversity and inclusion on said platform. Following their initial inquiry, I raised concern around the language of 'inclusion,' countering that inclusion implies bringing people into an already existing center. I asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled. My ability to garner the attention of a social media platform and then critique its work is not something I envisioned for myself when I started out in DH.

events.Text: My Day of DH (Digital Humanities) 2020 included an hour-long talk with a social media platform about diversity and inclusion on said platform.

Following their initial inquiry, I raised concern around the language of 'inclusion,' countering that inclusion implies bringing people into an already existing center. I asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled.
events.Main Action: They asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled.

Context: I asked if their BIPOC users really wanted to be included or if they wanted to be allowed to exist on the platform without being disproportionately surveilled.
Purpose: To explore whether current inclusion strategies fairly benefit all user groups, especially BIOPACs.
Method: Qualitative discussions among stakeholders involving surveys or interviews to gather opinions across diverse demographics.
Results: No explicit numerical results were extracted.
Analysis: Disagreements with existing knowledge regarding inclusivity implementations and their impact on BIPOC communities.
Challenge: Lack of standardized metrics for effective measurement of inclusivity while ensuring equitable access.
Ethical: Concerns surrounding fairness in AI-driven decision-making processes tied to inclusivity initiatives.
Implications: Necessitates nuanced approaches combining community feedback with technical safeguards against bias.
Contradictions: Discrepancies between desired inclusivity and perceived privacy benefits offered via Surveillance-Free Existence.

events.Text: My ability to garner the attention of a social media platform and then critique its work is not something I envisioned for myself when I started out in DH.
events.Main Action: garnish the attention of a social media platform

Context: My ability ... platform is not something I visualized for myself when I started out in DH.
Ethical: balance public discourse with maintaining authenticity
Implications: strengths in digital cultural production and critical engagement towards established systems
